citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Four adult dogs had untreated dental disease. Andre, an 8-year-old male Toy Poodle, (m/c# 7E10092628) had excessive
tarter build up on his incisors and molars. His molars were incased with tarter. His incisors had tartar build up covering
almost three quarters of the teeth and his gums were red and swollen. Philippe, a 12-year-old male Toy Poodle, (m/c#
0A01670943) had excessive tarter on the canines and molars. On the right side the molars were completely encased in
tarter with what looked like a line of white film buildup along the gumline. The gums were red and swollen. FeFe, a 5-year-
old Toy Poodle, (m/c# 933000320275138) had excessive tarter mainly on her canines and molars on both sides but was
even more excessive on her right side. The gum line is starting to recede away from the second tooth behind the canine
tooth and the rest of the gums are red and swollen. Mary, a 2-year-old Yorkie, (m/c# 7E10243938) had excessive tarter
mainly on her molars. However, on her left side the tooth behind the canine the gum line is starting to recede and there is
a white crème or film like material building up in between the tooth and the receding gum line. The rest of her gums are
red and swollen. Teeth and/or gum problems can be painful, can affect the ability to eat, and can result in tooth loss. The
licensee must establish an effective program of dental maintenance. The licensee must contact a veterinarian to have
these dental problems diagnosed and treated and must maintain medical records for the inspector to review.
The same four dogs had excessively matted hair all over their bodies. Maily found on their backs, their hind feet/hocks
and around their heads. Matted hair can result in skin problems, can be painful, and can compromise the hair’s ability to
provide protection from the heat or cold. The licensee must remove the matted from these animals and must establish an
effective program of haircoat maintenance.
TO BE CORRECTED BY APRIL 5, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Four adult dogs had untreated dental disease. Andre, an 8-year-old male Toy Poodle, (m/c# 7E10092628) had excessive 
tarter build up on his incisors and molars. His molars were incased with tarter. His incisors had tartar build up covering 
almost three quarters of the teeth and his gums were red and swollen. Philippe, a 12-year-old male Toy Poodle, (m/c# 
0A01670943) had excessive tarter on the canines and molars. On the right side the molars were completely encased in 
tarter with what looked like a line of white film buildup along the gumline. The gums were red and swollen. FeFe, a 5-year-
old Toy Poodle, (m/c# 933000320275138) had excessive tarter mainly on her canines and molars on both sides but was 
even more excessive on her right side. The gum line is starting to recede away from the second tooth behind the canine 
tooth and the rest of the gums are red and swollen. Mary, a 2-year-old Yorkie, (m/c# 7E10243938) had excessive tarter 
mainly on her molars. However, on her left side the tooth behind the canine the gum line is starting to recede and there is 
a white crème or film like material building up in between the tooth and the receding gum line. The rest of her gums are 
red and swollen. Teeth and/or gum problems can be painful, can affect the ability to eat, and can result in tooth loss. The 
licensee must establish an effective program of dental maintenance. The licensee must contact a veterinarian to have 
these dental problems diagnosed and treated and must maintain medical records for the inspector to review.  
 
The same four dogs had excessively matted hair all over their bodies. Maily found on their backs, their hind feet/hocks 
and around their heads. Matted hair can result in skin problems, can be painful, and can compromise the hair’s ability to 
provide protection from the heat or cold. The licensee must remove the matted from these animals and must establish an 
effective program of haircoat maintenance.  
 
TO BE CORRECTED BY APRIL 5, 2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee. 
 
 n
